page.title: 5.3.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will encounter two different growth patterns. You will think about and compare the patterns by performing calculations and using graphs. This lesson contains many opportunities for you to notice and make use of structure, for example, noticing that \(1,000+200+200+200+200\) can be expressed as \(1,000+200 \cdot 4\).

You will examine two types of patterns by looking at tables, noting that one type is characterized by common differences and the other by common ratios. Then you will match different representations with two contexts. This is an opportunity for you to notice structure in expressions.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Compare growth patterns using calculations and graphs.
  • Use words and expressions to describe patterns in tables of values.
  • Write expressions and create tables of values to represent them using descriptions of linear and exponential relationships.
  • Begin making connections between linear and exponential growth and the real world (especially financially).

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 5.3.1: Creating a Pictorial Representation of Exponential Growth
  • 5.3.2: Exploring Different Growth Patterns
    • 5.3.2: Self Check
  • 5.3.3: Compare and Contrast Two Patterns
    • 5.3.3: Self Check
  • 5.3.4: Match Expressions and Tables with Situations
    • 5.3.4: Self Check
  • 5.3.5: Describe Mathematically Changes in Growth

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 5.3.6: Practice
  • 5.3.7: Summary

page.title: 5.3.1: Creating a Pictorial Representation of Exponential Growth
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

There are some bacteria in a dish. Every hour, each bacterium splits into 3 bacteria.

  1. This diagram shows a bacterium in hour 0 and then hour 1. Draw what happens in hours 2 and 3.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Your answers may vary, but here is an example:


  1. How many bacteria are there in hour 2? Enter only integers.

Correct! There are 9 bacteria in hour 2.

Try again.

The correct answer is: There are 9 bacteria in hour 2.

  1. How many bacteria are there in hour 3? Enter only integers.

Correct! There are 27 bacteria in hour 3.

Try again.

The correct answer is: There are 27 bacteria in hour 3.

page.title: 5.3.2: Exploring Different Growth Patterns
page.contents:
Activity

You are walking along a beach, and your toe hits something hard. You reach down, grab onto a handle, and pull out a lamp! It is sandy. You start to brush it off with your towel. Poof! A genie appears.

He tells you, “Thank you for freeing me from that bottle! I was getting claustrophobic. You can choose one of these purses as a reward.”

  • Purse A, which contains $1,000 today. If you leave it alone, it will contain $1,200 tomorrow (by magic). The next day, it will be $1,400. This pattern of an additional $200 per day will continue.
  • Purse B, which contains 1 penny today. Leave that penny in there because tomorrow it will (magically) turn into 2 pennies. The next day, there will be 4 pennies. The amount in the purse will continue to double each day.
  1. How much money will be in Purse A after a 7-day week?  Enter only integers.

Correct! After 7 days, Purse A will contain $2,400 because it grows by $200 each day for 7 days.

Try again.

The correct answer is 2400. After 7 days, Purse A will contain $2,400 because it grows by $200 each day for 7 days.

  1. How much money will be in Purse B after a 7-day week? Enter only integers. 

Correct! Purse B will contain $1.28. It doubles each day for 7 days, so it will have \(1 \cdot 2^7\) or 128 cents (the 1 here represents the 1 cent for when the genie appeared).

Try again.

The correct answer is 1.28. Purse B will contain $1.28. It doubles each day for 7 days, so it will have \(1 \cdot 2^7\) or 128 cents (the 1 here represents the 1 cent for when the genie appeared).

  1. How much money will be in Purse A after two weeks? Enter only integers.

Correct! After 2 weeks, Purse A will contain an additional $1,400 for a total of $3,800.

Try again.

The correct answer is 3800. After 2 weeks, Purse A will contain an additional $1,400 for a total of $3,800.

  1. How much money will be in Purse B after two weeks? Enter only integers.

Correct! cPurse B will contain \(1 \cdot 2^{14}\) cents. This is 16,384 cents or $163.84.

Try again.

The correct answer is 163.84. Purse B will contain \(1 \cdot 2^{14}\) cents. This is 16,384 cents or $163.84.

  1. The genie later adds that he will let the money in each purse grow for three weeks. 

    1. How much money will be in Purse A in three weeks? Enter only integers.

Correct! After 3 weeks, Purse A will have an additional $1,400 during the third week for a total of $5,200.

Try again.

The correct answer is 5200. After 3 weeks, Purse A will have an additional $1,400 during the third week for a total of $5,200.

    1. How much money will be in Purse B in three weeks? Enter only integers.

Correct! Purse B will have 128 times as much money (compared to the end of two weeks) for a total of $20,971.52.

Try again.

The correct answer is 20971.52. Purse B will have 128 times as much money (compared to the end of two weeks) for a total of $20,971.52.

  1. Which purse contains more money after 30 days? Enter only integers.

Correct! Purse B will have a lot more money. Purse A will have \(1,000+30 \cdot 200\) or $7,000, which is much less than the doubling purse has on day 21.

Try again.

Incorrect. Purse B will have a lot more money. Purse A will have \(1,000+30 \cdot 200\) or $7,000, which is much less than the doubling purse has on day 21.

page.title: 5.3.2: Self Check
page.contents:
Olivia has two different job offers for babysitting next Saturday. 

  • Job 1: She will receive $5 for accepting the job, then $10 for every hour she works. 
  • Job 2: She will receive $1.50 for accepting the job, $3 after the first hour, $6 after the second hour, and for each additional hour her pay per hour will double.

Olivia can only work 3 hours. How much would she make at each job?

answer.answer_text: Olivia would make \(\$35\) at Job 1 and \(\$12\) at Job 2.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: \(\$12\) is the amount she would make after the third hour. To find the total, add: \(\$1.50+\$3+\$6+\$12\) or \($22.50\). The answer is Olivia would make \($35\) at Job 1 and \(\$22.50\) at Job 2.

answer.answer_text: Olivia would make \(\$35\) at Job 1 and \(\$22.50\) at Job 2.
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: Job 1 would be \(\$5 +\$10+\$10+\$10\) or \($35\). Job 2 would be \(\$1.50+\$3+\$6+\$12\) or \(\$22.50\).

answer.answer_text: Olivia would make \(\$25\) at Job 1 and \(\$10.50\) at Job 2.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This would be the amount for 2 hours, not 3. For Job 1, add another \(\$10\). For Job 2, add another \(\$12\). The answer is Olivia would make \(\$35\) at Job 1 and \(\$22.50\) at Job 2.

answer.answer_text: Olivia would make \(\$30\) at Job 1 and \(\$21\) at Job 2.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Be sure to add the amount she makes for accepting the job, \(\$5\) for Job 1 and \(\$1.50\) for Job 2. The answer is Olivia would make \(\$35\) at Job 1 and \(\$22.50\) at Job 2.

page.title: 5.3.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Exploring Linear and Exponential Growth

The tables listed below are modeling four different functions, all showing growth. Which one does not have the same growth pattern as the others?

Table A

\(x\)

\(y\)

1

8

2

16

3

24

4

32

8

64

Table B

\(x\)

\(y\)

0

0

2

16

4

32

6

48

8

64

Table C

\(x\)

\(y\)

0

1

1

4

2

16

3

64

4

256

Table D

\(x\)

\(y\)

0

4

1

8

2

12

3

16

4

20

When determining growth, there are a few ways to check. When given a table, you could graph each, or you could check the rate of change. Linear functions have a constant rate of change, where consecutive terms have a common difference. The common difference is a value that is added to or subtracted from consecutive terms to find the next term. Exponential functions have a constant ratio or common multiplier. The constant ratio is a value that is multiplied or divided from consecutive terms to find the next term.

  • Table A is linear and has a slope of 8 since the change in \(y\) is 8 and the change in \(x\) is 1.
  • Table B is also linear because the change in \(y\) is 16 and the change in \(x\) is 2 for a slope of 8.
  • Table C is an example of an exponential function. There is a common ratio instead of a common difference. Notice that each \(y\)-term is 4 times the previous term. Therefore, the common ratio is 4.
  • Table D is also linear with a common difference of 4.

Table C is the only exponential function. Therefore, it has a different growth pattern since Tables A, B, and D are linear.

Try It: Exploring Linear and Exponential Growth

The table shows the height, in centimeters, of the water in a swimming pool at different times since the pool started to be filled.

  1. Does the height of the water have a common difference or a common ratio? Explain how you know.
  2. What type of function is represented by the table? Explain how you know.

minutes

height

0

150

1

150.5

2

151

3

151.5

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

Here is how to determine the type of growth:

When you look at the \(y\)-values in the table, you notice that they are all 0.5 more than the previous term. That means there is a common difference of 0.5 and the function is linear.

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 5.3.3: Compare and Contrast Two Patterns
page.contents:
Activity

Here are graphs showing how the amount of money in the purses changes. Remember, Purse A starts with $1,000 and grows by $200 each day. Purse B starts with $0.01 and doubles each day.


  1. Which graph shows the amount of money in Purse A? Which graph shows the amount of money in Purse B? Explain how you know.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The graph containing \(P\) is Purse B, and the graph containing \(Q\) is Purse A. Purse B starts with less money than Purse A, so its graph will be lower at the beginning.



  1. Points \(P\) and \(Q\) are labeled on the graph. Explain what they mean in terms of the genie’s offer.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Point \(P\) says that 9 days after the genie has appeared, Purse B contains $5.42. Point \(Q\) says that 5 days after the genie has appeared, Purse A contains $2,000.



  1. What are the coordinates of the vertical intercept for each graph? Explain how you know.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

For Purse A, the vertical intercept is \((0,1,000)\) because when the genie appears (day 0), the purse has $1,000. For Purse B, the vertical intercept is \((0,0.01)\) because it only contains $0.01 when the genie appears.



  1. When does Purse B become a better choice than Purse A? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

According to the graphs, on day 19 and afterward, Purse B is worth more than Purse A. This can be seen on the graph since Purse B has a greater \(y\)-coordinate for the first time when \(x\) is 19.



  1. Knowing what you know now, which purse would you choose? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Answers vary. Purse B is worth more after 19 days, but there may be other considerations students may take into account.


While on a beach, your friend discovers a different genie. This genie also offers two purses to choose from, and he gives you the following graph to show how the money in each purse will grow. The set of triangular marks that lie on a line represent values in Purse A, and the set of square marks that make a curve represent those in Purse B.


  1. The genie is still deciding how many days he will let the money in the purses grow. Help your friend plan a strategy for picking the purse with more money while the genie thinks.

Enter your answer here:

Your answers may vary, but here is an example:

The vertical intercept for Purse B is lower, so Purse B starts off with less money than Purse A. The values in Purse B stay lower than the values in Purse A until day 10, when they appear to be the same. So Purse A is better up to day 10, and after that point Purse B becomes a better choice.



Extending Your Thinking

“Okay, okay,” the genie smiles, disappointed. “I will give you an even more enticing deal.” He explains that Purse B stays the same, but Purse A now increases by $250,000 every day. Which purse should you choose?

Enter your answer here:

Your answers may vary, but here is an example:

Purse B surpasses Purse A on day 30, with about $10.7 million in Purse B and only about $7.5 million in Purse A. So it’s better to choose Purse A if the amounts grow for less than 30 days, and it’s better to choose Purse B if they grow for 30 days or more.

page.title: 5.3.3: Self Check
page.contents: The graph shows the yearly balance, in dollars, in two investment accounts. Account A starts with $2,000. Account B starts with $1,000.

answer.answer_text: Account A grows more quickly as time goes on. Account B grows by the same amount each year.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: You may have confused the graphs of the two accounts. The graph of Account A forms a line and has a constant rate of change. The graph of Account B increases more quickly as the \(x\)-values increase. The answer is: Account A grows by the same amount each year. Account B grows more quickly as time goes on.

answer.answer_text: Account A grows by the same amount each year. Account B grows more quickly as time goes on
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: The graph of Account A forms a line and has a constant rate of change. The graph of Account B increases more quickly as time goes on.

answer.answer_text: Both accounts grow more quickly as time goes on.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The graph of Account A forms a line and has a constant rate of change. The answer is: Account A grows by the same amount each year. Account B grows more quickly as time goes on.

answer.answer_text: Both accounts grow by the same amount each year.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The graph of Account B increases more quickly as the \(x\)-values increase. The answer is: Account A grows by the same amount each year. Account B grows more quickly as time goes on.

page.title: 5.3.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Compare and Contrast Graphs

Compare and contrast the graphs of \(y=2x\) and \(y=2^x\).

To compare and contrast the graphs of these functions, you would first need to graph them.

Graph of \(y=2x\)

\(x\)

\(y=2x\)

–1

–2

0

0

1

2

2

4

Graph of \(y=2^x\)

\(x\)

\(y=2^x\)

–1

\(\frac12\)

0

1

1

2

2

4

Both equations have a 2 and an \(x\) in them, but in \(y = 2x\), \(x\) is multiplied by 2, and in \(y = 2^x\), 2 is the base and \(x\) is the exponent. If you graph the equations together on the same grid, it makes it easier to discuss the key features and compare the graphs.

  • The graphs intersect at \((1, 2)\) and \((2, 4)\).
  • \(y=2x\) has a \(y\)-intercept of \((0, 0)\). \(y-2^x\) has a \(y\)-intercept of \((0, 1)\).
  • When \(1<x<2\), \(y=2x\) is greater than \(y=2^x\).

Try It: Compare and Contrast Graphs

Compare and contrast the graphs of \(y=3x+1\) and \(y=3^x\).

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

Here is how to compare and contrast the graphs of \(y=3x+1\) and \(y=3^x\):

First, you need to graph both equations on the same plane.

Then you can compare key features of the graph, like points where they are equal and intercepts. Answers may vary, but here is a sample answer. Your answer may include all or part of the sample.

  • The functions are equal at their \(y\)-intercept \((0,1)\) and also at \((1.6, 5.8)\).
  • \( y=3x+1\) is linear and is greater when \(0<x<1.6\).
  • \( y=3^x\) is exponential and greater when \(x<0\) and \(x>1.6\).

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 5.3.4: Match Expressions and Tables with Situations
page.contents:
Activity

Here are verbal descriptions of two situations, followed by tables and expressions that could help answer one of the questions in the situations.

  • Situation 1: A person has 80 followers on social media. The number of followers triples each year. How many followers will she have after 4 years?
  • Situation 2: A tank contains 80 gallons of water and is getting filled at a rate of 3 gallons per minute. How many gallons of water will be in the tank after 4 minutes?

Use the descriptions of Situation 1 and Situation 2 to help you answer questions 1–6. Be prepared to explain how the table or expression answers the question.

  1. Which situation best describes \(80 \cdot 3 \cdot 3 \cdot 3 \cdot 3\)?

Correct! Situation 1

Try again.

Incorrect. The correct answer is Situation 1.

  1. Which situation best describes the following table?

\(x\)

0

1

2

3

4

\(y\)

80

240

720

2,160

6,480

Correct! Situation 1. The table shows the growth of the followers multiplied by 3 each year.

Try again.

Incorrect. The correct answer is Situation 1. The table shows the growth of the followers multiplied by 3 each year.

  1. Which situation best describes \(80+3+3+3+3\)?

Correct! Situation 2

Try again.

Incorrect. The correct answer is Situation 2.

  1. Which situation best describes \(80+4 \cdot 3\)?

Correct! Situation 2. \(4 \cdot 3\) is another way of expressing \(3+3+3+3\).

Try again.

Incorrect. The correct answer is Situation 2. \(4 \cdot 3\) is another way of expressing \(3+3+3+3\).

  1. Which situation best describes the following table?

\(x\)

0

1

2

3

4

\(y\)

80

83

86

89

92

Correct! Situation 2. The table shows the gallons of water in the tank increasing by 3 gallons each minute.

Try again.

Incorrect. The correct answer is Situation 2. The table shows the gallons of water in the tank increasing by 3 gallons each minute.

  1. Which situation best describes \(80\cdot 81\)?

Correct! Situation 1. The 81 comes from \(3 \cdot 3 \cdot 3 \cdot 3\).

Try again.

Incorrect. The correct answer is Situation 1.The 81 comes from \(3 \cdot 3 \cdot 3 \cdot 3\)



Video: Matching Verbal Situations to Expressions and Tables

Watch the following video to learn more about matching verbal representations of a function with tables and expressions.

page.title: 5.3.4: Self Check
page.contents: Which of the following is NOT an example of a way to represent a chain of stores that currently has 4 stores but plans to double the number of stores they have each year for the next 5 years?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: You are looking for an expression that does NOT represent the situation. This is an expression that represents having 4 stores and then multiplying by 2, or doubling the amount, 5 times to show 5 years. The answer is \(4 + 5 \cdot 2\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: They started with 4 stores, and doubling means multiplying by 2 for each additional year. You would need to multiply by 2 five times, NOT \(5 \cdot 2\).

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: You are looking for an expression that does NOT represent the situation. This is an expression that represents having 4 stores and doubling the amount each year for 5 years, or multiplying by 2 five times, or \(2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2\), which is 32. The answer is \(4 + 5 \cdot 2\).

answer.answer_text:
\(x\)

0

1

2

3

4

5

\(y\)

4

8

16

32

64

128
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: You are looking for an expression that does NOT represent the situation. This is the table that represents starting with 4 stores and multiplying by 2, or doubling, for 5 years. The answer is \(4 + 5 \cdot 2\).

page.title: 5.3.4: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Multiple Representations Verbal Scenario

Here are verbal descriptions of two situations, followed by tables and expressions that could help answer one of the questions in the situations.

A food company currently has 5 convenience stores. It is considering two plans for expanding its chain of stores.

Plan A: Open 20 new stores each year.

Plan B: Double the number of stores each year.

How many stores will there be after 5 years under each plan?

Match each representation (a table or an expression) with one situation. Be prepared to explain how the table or expression answers the question.

  1. \(5+20+20+20+20+20\)
  2. \(5 \cdot 32\)
  3. \(5 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2\)

  4. years

    0

    1

    2

    3

    4

    5

    number of stores

    5

    10

    20

    40

    80

    160

  5. \(5+100\)

  6. years

    0

    1

    2

    3

    4

    5

    number of stores

    5

    25

    45

    65

    85

    105

To determine which options go with which scenario, you first need to analyze each scenario.

Let’s look at Plan A.

  • Plan A is to open 20 new stores each year for a food company that currently has 5 convenience stores. In both scenarios, the initial value or starting point is 5 stores, which is why in each table the first value is \((0,5)\). If they are opening 20 additional stores each year, they are adding 20 stores to the total from the previous year. So in year 1 there would be 25 total stores, in year 2 there would be 45 total stores, and so on. These values are represented in option 6, so option 6 would represent Plan A.
  • The mathematical expressions contain either multiplication or addition. Plan A is ADDING 20 stores a year, so year 5 could be represented as option 1 because it would be the initial number of stores plus 20 per year for 5 years, or \(5 +20+20+20+20+20\).
  • Option 5 is also added, and represents Plan A since \(5 +20+20+20+20+20\) is the same as \(5+100\).

Let’s look at Plan B.

  • Plan B would also start at 5, but it says to double the number of stores each year. Double means to MULTIPLY by 2, so it would be \(5 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2\), which is option 3.
  • Since \(5 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2\) can be simplified to \(5 \cdot 32\), option 2 also represents Plan B.
  • Option 4 is the other table option, and as mentioned before, each table should have an initial value of 5 stores. Since Plan B is to double the number of stores, at the end of year 1 there should be 10 stores. When you check option 4, you can see that each term is double the term before.

Therefore, Plan A is options 1, 5, and 6, and Plan B is options 2, 3, and 4.

Try It: Multiple Representations Verbal Scenario

Represent the following scenario as a table and as two different mathematical expressions:

A tank contains 80 gallons of water and is getting filled at a rate of 3 gallons per minute. How many gallons of water will be in the tank after 4 minutes?

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer:

Here is how to represent the scenario:

The table would record time in minutes and total water in gallons. The initial value is 80 gallons, so the first entry would be \((0,80)\) and each additional entry would be 3 more than the previous entry.

Time
(in minutes)

0

1

2

3

4

Total water
(in gallons)

80

83

86

89

92

One mathematical expression would be 80 plus 3 repeated 4 times for the 4 minutes that passed, or \(80+3+3+3+3\). This could also be simplified to \(80+12\) or 92 gallons.

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 5.3.5: Describe Mathematically Changes in Growth
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

The tables show the cat population on two islands over several years. Describe mathematically, as precisely as you can, how the cat population on each island is changing.


year

0

1

2

3

4

number of cats on Meow Island

2

6

18

54

162

year

0

1

2

3

4

number of cats on Purr Island

2

6

10

14

18

Enter your answer here:

Your answers may vary, but here is an example:

The cat population on Meow Island is:

  • tripling each year
  • growing by a common ratio each year

The cat population on Purr Island is:

  • adding 4 cats each year
  • characterized by a common difference each year

page.title: 5.3.6: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. Which expression equals \(2^7\)?

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.3.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. The graph shows the yearly balance, in dollars, of investment account A. The table shows the yearly balance, in dollars, of investment account B.

    Number of years

    Amount in dollars

    0

    $2,000

    1

    $2,150

    2

    $2,300

    3

    $2,450

    4

    $2,600

    1. Investment A is a/n:

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 5.3.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is investment A is an exponential function. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Investment B is a/n:

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 5.3.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is investment B is a linear function. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. The graph shows the yearly balance, in dollars, of investment account A. The table shows the yearly balance, in dollars, of investment account B.

    Number of years

    Amount in dollars

    0

    $2,000

    1

    $2,150

    2

    $2,300

    3

    $2,450

    4

    $2,600

Which of the following statements are true? Select all that apply.

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.3.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are “Investment A has a common ratio” and “Investment B is growing by the same number of dollars each year.” You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Investment account 1 starts with a balance of $200 and doubles every year. Investment account 2 starts with $1,000 and increases by $100 each year.  How long does it take for each account to double?
    1. How many years will it take investment account 1 to double?

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 5.3.1 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is investment account 1 will double after 1 year. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. How many years will it take investment account 2 to double?

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 5.3.1 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is investment account 2 will double after 10 years. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. A population of ants is 10,000 at the start of April. Since then, it triples each month. How many ants will there be 1 month later? 

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.3.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 30,000. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. A population of ants is 10,000 at the start of April. Since then, it triples each month. Which values complete the table?

    months since April

    number of ants

    0

    10,000 

    1

    30,000 

    2

     

    3

     

    4

     

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 5.3.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 90,000, 270,000, 510,000. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. A population of ants triples each month. If there are \(n\) ants in one month, which expression represents how many ants there will be one month later?

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.3.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(3n\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. A swimming pool contains 500 gallons of water. A hose is turned on, and it fills the pool at a rate of 24 gallons per minute. Which expression represents the amount of water in the pool, in gallons, after 8 minutes?

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 5.3.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(500+24 \cdot 8\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. The population of a city is 100,000. It doubles each decade for 5 decades. Select all expressions that represent the population of the city after 5 decades.

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 5.3.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(100,000 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2 \cdot 2\), \(100,000 \cdot 2^5\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Bank account C starts with $10 and doubles each week. Bank account D starts with $1,000 and grows by $500 each week.

    When will account C contain more money than account D?

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 5.3.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is account C will contain more money than account D after 10 weeks. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 5.3.7: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Compare growth patterns using calculations and graphs.
  • Use words and expressions to describe patterns in tables of values.
  • Write expressions and create tables of values to represent them using descriptions of linear and exponential relationships.
  • Begin making connections between linear and exponential growth and the real world (especially financially).

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 5.3.1: Creating a Pictorial Representation of Exponential Growth
    • In this activity, you create a pictorial representation of exponential growth.
  • 5.3.2: Exploring Different Growth Patterns
    • In this activity, you explored two growth patterns and learned that a doubling pattern eventually grows very, very large, even with a small starting value.
  • 5.3.2: Self Check
  • 5.3.3: Compare and Contrast Two Patterns
    • In this activity, you compared and contrasted the two patterns visually. You did this by making sense of the provided graphs and used them to answer questions in the context of the scenario. You recalled that a quantity that grows by adding the same amount at each step forms a line when plotted. Also, after viewing an example, you learned that a quantity that grows by the same ratio or factor at each step forms a curve when plotted.
  • 5.3.3: Self Check
  • 5.3.4: Match Expressions and Tables with Situations
    • In this activity, you studied two stories characterized by different growth patterns and then matched expressions and tables with the two situations.
  • 5.3.4: Self Check
  • 5.3.5: Describe Mathematically Changes in Growth
    • In this activity, you described mathematically, as precisely as you could, how a population changed over time.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 5.3.6: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
